text: it's great to be with you again I was
thinking about the one of my most
memorable speeches it was to my
daughter's fifth grade I was invited to
come and give a speech to her for fifth
grade and I gave a stem-winder of a
speech to that fifth grade I talked
about the transformative power of
technology in their ability to do a
better job of performing public service
I talked about the the need to detect
and prevent and preempt cyber security
attacks as we move forward to the future
I talked about the need for data center
consolidation and moved to the cloud and
I got very polite applause from that 5th
grade with one exception there's one
little girl in the corner arms akimbo
the big scowl on her face and I went up
to her and I said you didn't like my
speech she said no I thought it was
boring my daughter can see the stricken
look at my face and to comfort me she
came running up and said Oh dad don't
listen to her she just repeats what
everyone else says so being in public
life and giving speeches could be a
humbling effect it's great to be with
you again and you know since we last met
about a year ago where we did a fireside
chat at this the same conference three
kind of critical things have happened
big big changes one is we passed the
first kind of comprehensive
transformative legislation to change how
we managed IT procurement management in
the federal government not a trivial
thing federal government is a
trendsetter it sets design standards it
often sets best practices and it's an 84
billion dollar-a-year market and its
really desperately in need of reform
unfortunately a lot of that 84 billion
dollars is still used
for maintenance of legacy systems in
fact we still use COBOL in the federal
government the only good news about that
is the Chinese don't know how to hack
into it but we could free up 2003 30
billion of that 80 to 84 billion a year
and reinvest it to make ourselves much
more efficient much more productive and
to use technology as something other
than a commodity one of the things we
have to do in the federal government is
sort of change the mindset technology is
not just another commodity to be managed
it is a process that can transform how
we do business how we provide services
and to actually rethink and reinvent how
we how we do business in the federal
government and that's really critical
the second big thing that happened which
may sound odd but I think it's a real
milestone is the GAO put IT management
and procurement in its high risk list it
produces a high risk list every year 50
60 items and for the first time it put
this one in that list that's important
because it gets the attention of all
federal agencies and all federal
managers that this is important this
must be addressed it's long overdue but
it's a welcome change and the third big
change since we last met a year ago of
course happened very recently the most
catastrophic personal information breach
in the history of the federal government
was just announced recently by the
Office of Personnel Management
compromising at least 4.2 million
Americans personal information people
who worked do work for the federal
government or once worked for the
federal government this is also
important
in many many respects but not least of
which is it exposes an antiquated
technology system in the federal
government and what can go wrong when
you don't reinvest when you don't make
the investments you need to make to stay
ahead of the game the vulnerability is
obvious some of the systems are so old
encryption is not possible and they were
easy targets for a cybersecurity attack
and this wasn't just any cybersecurity
attack we're pretty sure it was an
organized systematic well-funded well
thought-through attack by the Chinese
government what the Chinese want to do
with the personal information of 4.2
million federal workers is not clear
what is clear however is that this is a
wake-up call for the United States we've
had lots of breaches not only the
federal government but in the private
sector as well technology can be
transformative empowering think about
the you know the incredible changes
technology is driven in every aspect of
our life but there's a soft underbelly
of Technology the vulnerability and
protecting privacy protecting databases
really important and unfortunately the
federal government is not well equipped
uniformly to do that and it must partner
with the private sector to do that and
that's why we passed a law called potara
the federal information technology
acquisition reform act a mouthful we
prefer to call it aissa connolly doesn't
that ring off the lips better even that
fifth grade I talked to might remember
that but it kind of it tries to bring
the federal government into the 21st
century and how it manages its IT
procurement
how its organized hierarchically to do
that you know spread out over 24 federal
agencies we have 250 people with the
title CIO think about that that is a
system that goes like this in a sense
nobody's in charge nobody ultimately is
accountable nobody has the
responsibility and the authority to make
purchasing decisions deployment
decisions in the light we've got to
change that and and and try to
rationalize the hierarchical structure
in the federal government that again
that may not seem like anything but an
arcane bureaucratic concern but the
federal government is huge and and we're
talking about some very serious things
how we manage national security how we
manage defense how we manage the
provision of healthcare how we manage
our own personnel these are huge issues
involving huge numbers from Social
Security to Medicare and they have to be
managed in a different way because of
Technology and so there's an opportunity
as well as a risk this latest breach is
something that we really need to pay
attention to because we're kind of in
this low level but very intense cyber
cold war with the Chinese and the
Russians and we need to better gird
ourselves to protect our country our
assets our public utilities and our
privacy and we have an opportunity to do
that with this new legislation I'm
hoping we will seize it the good news is
we are going to seize it technology can
be such a force for good it can be a
force multiplier in the public sector
that we've never seen before and some
agencies are doing very well with it
using it for things like telework
and in terms of protecting against cyber
security the OPM breach that has
received so much attention is masked a
little bit by the number of cyber
attacks we have OPM is hit by 10 million
cyberattacks a month that's one agency
imagine what DHS Department of Homeland
Security is dealing with or the Pentagon
is dealing with the CIA partners up with
the private sector and actually made the
investments necessary to protect itself
and it's a model maybe for a lot of
other federal agencies but in Congress
we've got to make sure the resources is
there to make those investments to help
address the legacy systems to eliminate
duplication to move to the cloud in a
much more efficient way partnering with
the private sector we need to protect
our people IRS is a great example the
average age of a computer replaced at
IRS is now somewhere between seven and
nine years in the private sector the
standards 223 as a result we have a lot
of hard drive crashes we have 90 1000
employees serving the entire country in
the IRS and how they kind of hold on
information archive it that can be
retrieved subsequently if your file
comes up again here is their instruction
print and save because the computers are
now so old and so unreliable that's the
most reliable way to manage the tax
system of the United States we can't
accept that we have to make the
investments necessary to modernize the
IRS and make it a lot more efficient to
serve the public now when you don't it
isn't just that it's Anna fish
it isn't just that they lose the ability
for customer service in a qualitative
sense but it's a direct threat to
American taxpayers in one of the most
one of the fastest growing crimes in
america and its cost free from a
criminal point of view is the diversion
of refunds at the IRS you know Willie
Sutton used to say when asked why he
robbed banks he said that's where the
money is today he'd say I go to the IRS
and I divert those refunds because it's
so easy to do and a lot of it has to do
with antiquated technology that doesn't
protect citizens so whether one likes or
doesn't like the IRS this isn't an
ideological question it's a matter of
serving the American taxpayer and
protecting the American taxpayer from
this kind of cyber attack which is a
growing crime so across the board we
have challenges that are very real in
the public sector that mirror in many
ways some of the challenges in the
private sector Bank of America gets 140
million cyberattacks a year in one bank
we saw the breach on customer data with
a target and some other private sector
entities in the last several years so we
know the threat is ubiquitous people are
testing the system testing the
vulnerability well the United States had
to be at the forefront of being able to
detect and deter not way behind always
reacting to an event that already has
happened and that's my goal and I hope
it's yours as well the good news is we
certainly have the entrepreneurial
skills to do that we have the domain
expertise especially in the private
sector with which we can partner we're
not helpless but we need to be willing
to make the investments in order to reap
the returns and and that's a key key
message for all of us these investments
in technology have a high rate
of return in terms of what the power us
to be able to do and in terms of meeting
other goals like privacy protection so
hopefully as we move forward we'll take
cognizance of these three big
developments that have occurred since we
last time met and hopefully a year from
now I'll be able to report a lot more
progress thank you so much for being
here today god bless you all thank you
